concept_definition: a large natural elevation of the Earth's surface rising abruptly from the surrounding level; a large steep hill, usually higher and steeper than a hill
a naturally raised area of land, smaller than a mountain, often with a rounded summit
a low area of land between hills or mountains, often with a river or stream running through it
a naturally flowing body of water, usually freshwater, that moves along a channel from higher to lower elevations and empties into another body of water (such as a sea, lake, or another river).
a large body of fresh or salt water surrounded by land
A vast body of salt water that covers most of the Earth's surface and is divided into major areas such as the Atlantic, Pacific, Indian, Arctic, and Southern Oceans.
A large body of salt water that covers most of the Earth's surface and is partly enclosed by land; one of the principal divisions of the ocean.
A shore of a body of water, especially a sandy or pebbly area by the sea or a lake where people can walk, sunbathe, or swim.
The land along the edge of the sea; the coastline or shore.
A piece of land completely surrounded by water and smaller than a continent.
A piece of land that is surrounded by water on three sides and connected to a larger landmass on the remaining side.
a large area of land that receives very little precipitation and has sparse vegetation, typically characterized by sand or rock and extreme temperature variations
An elevated and flat piece of land that is substantially higher than the surrounding terrain
a deep, narrow valley with steep, often rocky sides, usually carved by a river
a steep rock face, especially at the edge of the sea or a mountain
a natural underground hollow or chamber in rock, typically large enough for a human to enter
a steep descent of a river or stream, where water falls from a height over rocks or a cliff
A large, slow-moving mass of ice formed from compacted snow that flows downhill or spreads outward under its own weight, often shaping the landscape by erosion and deposition.
A mountain or hill with a crater or vent through which molten rock, ash, and gases are or have been erupted from the Earth's crust; also any similar feature on another planet.
The region of the atmosphere and outer space that appears as a dome over the Earth, seen as the area where clouds, the sun, moon, and stars appear.
The star at the center of the Solar System that provides light and heat to Earth and around which the planets orbit.
The natural satellite that orbits Earth, visible (usually at night) by reflected light from the Sun; also used to refer to similar satellites of other planets.
a luminous celestial body made of plasma that generates energy through nuclear fusion and appears as a point of light in the night sky; any such object (e.g., the Sun).
A visible mass of tiny water droplets or ice crystals suspended in the atmosphere, typically forming various shapes and often producing precipitation.
Water that falls from clouds in drops; precipitation in the form of liquid water.
Frozen crystalline precipitation that falls from clouds as white flakes, forming a layer on the ground when temperatures are low.
a natural movement of air, especially a perceptible breeze or a flow of air produced by atmospheric pressure differences
a violent weather event characterized by strong winds, often with rain, snow, thunder, or lightning
A thick cloud of tiny water droplets suspended in the air near the ground that reduces visibility.
Frozen water; a solid form of water produced when temperature falls below 0°C (32°F), often appearing as clear or opaque solid, used for cooling or forming ice sheets and icicles.
A measure of how hot or cold something is, typically determined by a thermometer and expressed in degrees on a standard scale (such as Celsius or Fahrenheit).
a prediction or estimate of future events, especially of weather or economic conditions
the planet on which we live; soil or ground
the solid surface of the earth
combustion producing heat and light
a solid mineral material; a stone
a way or track laid down for walking
a celestial body orbiting a star
a small narrow river
a surface with one end higher than the other
a hot glowing body of burning gas
a cloud of tiny water droplets in the air
a rough path; a mark left by something
a narrow channel dug in the ground
a ridge of water moving across the surface
a path through wild areas
the loud noise following lightning
a particular position, point, or area in space; a location; a portion of space designated for a purpose.
the earth with all its countries and people; the universe; human society or civilization.
a way or track laid down for walking or made by continual treading; a course of action or way of life.
an area of open land, especially one used for cultivation or pasture; a sphere of activity or study.
the solid surface of the earth; soil or earth; an area of land used for a specific purpose.
the solid part of the earth's surface not covered by water; ground or soil; a country or realm.
the planet we live on; the ground or soil; the world as distinct from heaven or space.
a large natural mass of stone forming a hill, cliff, or promontory; a smaller piece of stone.
the outside part or uppermost layer of something; the top of a body of water or land.
a small, narrow river; a continuous flow of liquid, air, or gas.
the land along the edge of a sea, lake, or other large body of water; the coast.
a celestial body moving in an elliptical orbit around a star; the Earth.
a nation with its own government; rural areas as opposed to cities; a region with particular characteristics.
